My brother and I are both successful adults. Our social worker mother worked full time at Red Cross from six weeks after I was born in 1948 until he was born in 1951. After that she worked part time at home coordinating volunteers who visited "shut-ins", debriefing them by phone. Then came some short term jobs. When he was in 1st grade and I in 4th she took a year-long full-time assignment. It ended in June. By October it was clear to us that she was not fun to be around when she wasn't working. We took direct action, strongly suggesting that everyone would be much happier if she went back to work. I think Daddy concurred in private; he was already doing a lot of chores anyway, as were we. When we looked back on this many years later all four of us agreed that we had benefitted.
Caveats:
1. Both parents were working stable-schedule 40 hour weeks most of the time. We had family dinners almost every night, during the week cooked mostly by whichever child got home first. Lots of other time was spent together.
2. We could have lived a lower middle class life on one of their salaries. As it was there was money to be comfortable and stretch our experiences a bit.
3. She did not like housework and was mildly disabled; we probably would have ended up doing a lot of it anyway. What we got was a deal where we did that and got allowances much larger than most of our peers so we did not have to do paper routes, baby sitting, etc. for spending money.
4. This is an anecdote.

I feel it's helpful if one parent can stay home, it doesn't have to be the mother. But I certainly felt neglected as a child and have subsequently had problems because both of my parents worked.

I don't understand why people have children who don't actually have time for them.

Might the "I can't drive 55" (mph) thing be similar to the broken windows theory?

Nixon, I think it was, lowered speed limits to 55mph to reduce consumption of gasoline during the first embargo period. In a 1969 Ford, 55 mph might have seemed somewhat fast. But cars kept getting better. Smoother engines, quieter inside, better tires and suspensions, and pretty soon 55 seemed like you were crawling. Throw in the intercity distanes that Americans faced and the decency of interstate highways and pretty soon people were breaking the law all over the place.

This is an important comment.  But next question is, how and why are there so many insane?  And if insane, how can they bond over it?   Let's spend the money of this (vs, say NSA, prison for non-violent offenders, etc.) and see if there is a more proactive, productive path to eradicating terror.

All our actions are neurophysiological responses, so any action that does not conform to societal norms by definition can be classified as a mental illness.

If you want to express the generally accepted notion that all terrorists and the people who sympathize with them are nuts, then you are preaching to the choir. However, there is a world of difference between Jared Loughner, who shot Gabrielle Giffords and a number of other people, and terrorists like Bin Laden etc. Loughner is a schizophrenic, he could not differentiate between right and wrong. IMO he should not be in prison, he should be under psychiatric care. What we are doing to him is cruel and shameful. Tsarnaev is an entirely different matter. He and all other terrorists very clearly can differentiate between right and wrong. They go a long way to rationalize their actions.
What you are saying is that it is wrong to kill terrorists. I beg to differ. There is no other practical way to protect ourselves. Or are you planning on warehousing all the world's terrorists in America's prisons.? Then we better start building now, there are a lot of ISIS folks waiting to enter that retirement community.

Where do revolutionaries fit on your diagnostic spectrum Doctor?  Would you consider, for instance, some of the American Revolutionaries mentally ill because they attacked Tory civilians and property?

Terrorism is a symptom of a mental illness. The illness has not yet been identified in the Dsm, but it will be. ESPECIALLY in the case of someone so young, the notion that this horrific act could be the result of sane, rational deliberation is absurd. By definition, sane, rational people do not do what the Tsaenaevs did. They don't do what ISIS does. They don't do what Mc Veigh did, or Bin Laden, or any of them. There is a specific set of paranoid, narcissistic, delusional and incoherent mental conditions which give rise to the illness that results in terroristic behavior.
The death penalty is not applicable to the insane. An evolved, secure society does not kill the mentally ill in punishment. Only insecure, unformed, and critically weak societies do so; and the decision to apply the penalty of death in this case is evidence of the weakness of the United States, not of its strength.
